docs.summary: Thanks to React's component-oriented architecture, the React community has been naturally gravitating towards design systems as a way of standardizing our respective design languages into reusable components. When done successfully, it suddenly becomes trivial to translate standard designs into code. In fact, we may even find that this translation step starts to feel somewhat redundant. In a world of components, how should our design processes change? How should our tooling change? How should we, as React developers, better enable this change? In this talk, we'll look at the current state of design and development, and where we could goâ€”if we're willing to push for it.
docs.title: Designing with React - Mark Dalgleish

docs.summary:
Published on May 3, 2019Talk recording from React Amsterdam 2019 Conference https://react.amsterdam# Sharing Code Between React and React-Native: What Not to Share# React Native TrackReact and React-Native allow a learn once write anywhere paradigm.
This is great, because one tech team can build both your web app and native mobile experience.
There have been a couple of efforts to build a unifying technology to write an application once and have it work on both web and native.
There is value in only sharing your business and state logic; keeping your render code separate.
In this talk I will give real examples from my work with MADE.COM, migrating their web and mobile application to React and React-Native with code sharing as a primary objective.
docs.title: Sharing Code Between React and React-Native: What Not to Share - Ben Ellerby

docs.summary: Next.js is one of the most convenient and powerful ways of developing React apps on the web. With powerful features out of the box such as code-splitting, server-side rendering and powerful optimizations, this talk discusses the exciting next steps for Next.js.
docs.title: Next for Next.js - Tim Neutkens

docs.summary: React on its own has a very small API surface. Most of the magic happens in user-land. But, there's a lot out there: Higher order components, Render props, Compound components? Provider methods? Learn which component pattern will make your codebase better in which use case.
docs.title: Refactoring React - Siddharth Kshetrapal

docs.summary:
TrackReact is a brilliant JavaScript library for building simple and complex user interfaces.
In our eagerness to apply to React to our most complex of problems and ship solutions today, we can get lost in the ðŸŒ²ðŸŒ²ðŸŒ² forest of abstractions ðŸŒ²ðŸŒ²ðŸŒ².
To strip away all abstraction until what we're left with is the bare bones.
The better you understand abstraction, the more effective you will be at using it.
In this talk, we'll get more effective at using React Hooks, React Suspense, and JSX.
docs.title: Requisite React - Kent C. Dodds

docs.summary: The first three talks from React Conf 2018 by Sophie Alpert, Dan Abramov, and Ryan Florence.
docs.title: React Today and Tomorrow and 90% Cleaner React With Hooks

docs.summary:
This is a talk from Barcelona FutureJS 2014 (http://futurejs.org).

In this talk I'll be discussing why we built a virtual DOM, how it compares to other systems, and its relevance to the future of browser technologies.
docs.title: Pete Hunt - The Secrets of React's Virtual DOM (FutureJS 2014)

docs.summary:
We've talked a lot about big concepts such as the Virtual DOM, re-rendering the entire app on every update with a diff algorithm, server-side rendering.

But there's another side to it: all the design decisions that make React work for large projects.
docs.title: Christopher Chedeau: Why does React Scale?
State Machines Meet React Hooks - Zain Fathoni
docs.summary: Surprised of too many things went wrong in your UI components? and Ever felt that freeing your components from bugs is a never-ending endeavor? Join Zains journey in solving those kinds of issues using State Machines.

Reactâ€™s unique strength is bringing to JavaScript development some of the benefits previously exclusive to more radically functional languages such as Elm and ClojureScript, without forcing you to completely eschew local state or rewrite code with exclusively immutable data structures.
In this talk, Dan will demonstrate how React can be used together with Webpack Hot Module Replacement to create a live editing environment with time travel that supercharges your debugging experience and transforms the way you work on real apps every day.
docs.title: Dan Abramov - Live React: Hot Reloading with Time Travel at react-europe 2015

docs.summary: It's amazing how React allows you to build scalable and maintainable UI, adapt for requirement changes and stay DRY.
docs.title: Kent C Dodds - Simply React

docs.summary:
Automated tests are an important part of raising your confidence when releasing software.
They can speed you up or slow you down depending on how you write them and which form of testing you focus your test writing on.

In this talk, weâ€™ll cover the value of automated testing and where your efforts should be focused to strike the best balance of confidence and effort.
docs.title: Kent C. Dodds â€“ Write tests. Not too many. Mostly integration.

docs.summary:
React 16 was released several months ago. Even though this update was largely API-compatible, the rewritten internal engine included new long-requested features and opened the door for exciting future possibilities.

In this talk, Dan will share the React teamâ€™s vision for what the future of React might look like, including some never before seen prototypes.

Whether or not you use React, Dan hopes that you will find something valuable in this talk and that it sparks new conversations about building delightful user interfaces.
docs.title: Dan Abramov: Beyond React 16 | JSConf Iceland 2018
